qas.question: In which area in London is Imperial's main campus located?
What is the area inside of South Kensington where Imperial is located known as?
In which decade did the expansion of the South Kensington campus being?
Who designed the Imperial Institue that was a victim of Imperial's expansion in the 1950s & 1960s?
Which landmark still remains from the Imperial Institue after Imperial's expansion?
What school's main campus is located in North Kent?
What area of Kent is begining to develop cultural and academic institutions?

plausible_answers.text: Natural History Museum, the Science Museum, the Victoria and Albert Museum

qas.question: What are some of the institutions are across from Imperial's main campus?
What campus reduced its size in the 1950's and 1960's?
What campus was absorbed by the Imperial Institute?

context: <b5_0>Imperial's<b5_0/> main campus is located in the <a0_0>South Kensington<a0_0/> area of central London. It is situated in an area of South Kensington, known as <a1_0><b6_0>Albertopolis<b6_0/><a1_0/>, which has a high concentration of cultural and academic institutions, adjacent to the <b7_0>Natural History Museum, the Science Museum, the Victoria and Albert Museum<b7_0/>, the Royal College of Music, the Royal College of Art, the Royal Geographical Society and the Royal Albert Hall. Nearby public attractions include the Kensington Palace, Hyde Park and the Kensington Gardens, the National Art Library, and the Brompton Oratory. The expansion of <b8_0>the <b9_0>South Kensington campus<b9_0/><b8_0/> in the <a2_0>1950s<a2_0/> & 1960s absorbed the site of the former Imperial Institute, designed by <a3_0>Thomas Collcutt<a3_0/>, of which only the 287 foot (87 m) high <a4_0>Queen's Tower<a4_0/> remains among the more modern buildings.
